fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why did the HiSPEed slow down between 10:30 AM ET to 12:50 PM ET?
In HiSPEed, we have workers constantly poll messages from the main and throttling MQ queues. It was observed that(during the problematic time),90% of the workers were trying(re-trying) to process the problematic flow from the throttling queue. This resulted in only a few workers handling the current data from the main queue, leading to the slow processing and backlog in the queue. 

Why 2: Why 90% of the workers were trying(re-trying) to process from the throttling queue?
This was caused by the problematic flow which keeps on retrying and rolling back from April 10. There are a certain number of retries allowed at Hispeed and Once all retries are exhausted, Hispeed will track the flow as red in inflight. During an attempt to track the flow as red in Inflight(after exhausting all the retries), the system encountered an exception while converting Process Data XML to a process event using the tracking XSLT, because the Process Data contained a malformed XML tag. This malformed tag resulted in an invalid XML structure upon conversion(from SPE process Data to Process Data XML).
While investigating On 4/14, the number of attempts to track that flow red is 219326 in the specified time(10:30-12:50)    


Why 3: Why did the above flow start causing this issue in HiSPEed?
On April 10, a modification was implemented in one of the customer flows that interacts with Hispeed (Source System: Search And Replace, Destination System: SPE02). This flow has created an issue that results in the invalid XML structure during the Process Data XML to a process event using the tracking XSLT

fields.customfield_12109:
# Dev
D1 Monitoring missing? - While monitoring for queue depth >10,000 is in place, this specific alert was acknowledged but not acted upon in a timely manner due to parallel focus on the MQ incident PTB. This was a case of human oversight, as such alerts typically auto-resolve within 10 minutes and were mistakenly deprioritized for later review. To prevent recurrence, we’ve identified the need to (1) improve awareness, (2) reinforce adherence to alert-handling protocols across the team, and (3) implement additional threshold-based alerts at 20k, 50k, and 100k to serve as escalating reminders and ensure timely action.
D2 Missed to create incident. - Since the alert was overlooked, the corresponding incident was not created.
D3 Missed to inform Support - Same as above (the missed alert contributed to the issue as well.)

# Support
S1 Late client notification

fields.description:
HiSPEed experienced a data delay in North America Production. Processing became slow because of some bad data which continuously keeps on retry and roll back.

 
h3.
fields.customfield_10805:
1. On April 10, a modification was implemented in one of the customer flows that interacts with Hispeed (Source System: Search And Replace, Destination System: SPE02).
2. Upon reaching Hispeed, the system fails to return any response or tracking information to either Orch or Inflight.
3. Consequently, the flow persistently retries and rolls back. Once all retries are exhausted, Hispeed attempts to track the flow as red.
4. During this red tracking attempt, Hispeed encounters an exception while converting Process Data XML to a process event using the tracking XSLT.
5. Upon examination, it was discovered that the Process Data contained a malformed XML tag (derived from a previous command message), which, upon conversion to XML, resulted in an invalid XML structure.
6. The conversion of this invalid XML to Process Event XML via XSLT transformation triggers an error (com.sun.org.apache.xml.internal.utils.WrappedRuntimeException: The character sequence "]]>" must not appear in content unless used to mark the end of a CDATA section).
7. As a result, during the red tracking attempt, Hispeed proceeds with the error, failing to transmit any information to Orch/Inflight.
8. The transaction is rolled back and re-queued for further retry attempts.
9. This cycle persisted from April 10 to April 14, until the processing delay was addressed.
10. In total, 219,326 attempts were made to track the flow red during the specified period (10:30 AM ET to 12:50 PM ET on April 14).
11. On April 14, the message, which was 365966 seconds old, was found to be causing 90% of the worker/threads to process the bad flow from the throttling queue, while only a few were handling the current data. This led to a buildup of backlog for the current data.
12. Following a restart around 12:50 PM ET, the workers were re-initialized and commenced processing from the Input queue.
13. The problematic transaction (which created this issue) was transferred to the hold queue for further analysis.

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why was Data deleted ?
Ans: Because the EMT file cleanup service by mistake, deleted the entire data files in the outbound folder. 

Why 2: Why did EMT Cleanup process run and deleted files that should not have been deleted ?
Ans: Because it ran in multi-threaded mode and was not designed to be run like that and some config files were overwritten in memory causing it to misinterpret the config values.

Why 3: Why did EMT cleanup process run in multi threaded mode ?
Ans: Ideally the cleanup process only takes under 5 mins to run and then service sleeps and then runs again every  5 mins. In this case, the file cleanup process took 3-4 hours to cleanup as compared to the usual 5 mins. So after 5 mins, it spawned a new thread to delete files, while the existing thread was still running and since it was not designed to run in multi threaded mode, it messed up the memory locations, thereby deleting the wrong folder locations.

Why 4: Why was the existing thread still running?
Ans: Because there were millions of files pending to be deleted, that it took around 3-4 hours to complete the task.

Why 5: Why were there millions of files pending to be cleaned up.?
Ans: Because the file cleanup service was not turned on after the C:Centre WebMethods software upgrade. So this accumulated 7 days worth of files of which the majority were the temp files which need cleanup every 5 mins causing 10's of gigs worth of data pending to be deleted.

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why did Kafka become unavailable?
Kafka is a distributed system. We have our defaults set to allow for 2 system failure tolerance. However, it is possible for clients to chose their tolerances. In this situation, we lost 2 systems which causes 2 replica topics to have offline partitions and 3 replica topics to have ISR of 1. Any client expecting ISR of 2 would fail.

Why 2: Why did the systems Kafka brokers are hosted on fail?
One of the systems had a hardware failure where a part had to be replaced.
The other froze up, became unresponsive and had to be physically power cycled.
These two failures happened to overlap.
fields.customfield_12106: To the best of our knowledge, one of our offerings has been affected and subsequently their customers. Here is an RCA that describes that: RC-1413
fields.customfield_10711:
21st of March, 2025 at 03:59 GMT: Raid controller fails on system p2prdicusfra020kafka003.fs.local and infrastructure team receives an alert of the failure.
21st of March, 2025 at 03:59 GMT: P2PaaS Infrastructure acknowledges the alert and engages.
21st of March, 2025 at 15:17 GMT: Infrastructure team engages IBM cloud team due to having disk issues on the system once they have managed to rescue it and communicate to it.
21st of March, 2025 at 17:00 GMT: System p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local freezes up and becomes unresponsive.
21st of March, 2025 at 17:02 GMT: Infrastructure team has acknowledged the alert and engages the issue.
21st of March, 2025 at 17:24 GMT: Infrastructure team has recovered the system p2prdicusfra020kafka003.fs.local with the help of IBM cloud engineers. Kafka data has been lost and needs to be replicated from the other systems in the cluster. Core Services team cannot start the kafka process before system p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local is recovered and synchronized back into the cluster and therefore delays the repair for the application until it can be safely done.
21st of March, 2025 at 17:44 GMT: Infrastructure team has engaged with the IBM cloud team about the system p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local.
21st of March, 2025 at 17:50 GMT: System p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local gets recovered by power cycling it. (unplug and plug back in)
21st of March, 2025 at 17:52 GMT: System p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local begins automatic recovery. (due to unclean application shutdown, kafka needs to repair its partitions).
21st of March, 2025 at 18:31 GMT: System p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local has synchronized with the cluster and resumes full operations. (Note that clients may have been able to use the cluster unimpeded once again between the broker loading the partitions and synchronizing the partitions so their timings may differ. This is the time when Core Services team was confident that the cluster was functioning at an acceptable capacity.) Incident mitigated.
21st of March, 2025 at 18:32 GMT: Core Services team starts the Kafka application process on the system p2prdicusfra020kafka003.fs.local. The broker starts instantly due to not having data to repair. Instead it begins the process of copying the data over from the other members in the cluster.
22nd March, 2025 at 06:45 GMT: Kafka broker on system  p2prdicusfra020kafka003.fs.local has finished copying the data and is now fully synchronized with the other members in the cluster. The cluster has returned to its full capacity. Incident resolved.
fields.description:
h2. Description

Two systems have failed on the Kafka cluster in Frankfurt data-center. This in turn starts an outage for all clients that require Kafka ISR (In Sync Replicas) for their topics to be at least 2.
h2. Rough times for the incident.

Started: 21st of March, 2025 at 17:00 GMT
Mitigated: 21st of March, 2025 at 18:31 GMT
Resolved: 22nd of March, 2025 at 06:45 GMT

p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local

-> System down between 17:00 and 17:50 GMT on 21st of March, 2025
-> Kafka broker availability at 18:31 GMT on 21st of March, 2025
p2prdicusfra020kafka003.fs.local

-> System down between 03:59 and 17:24 GMT on 21st of March, 2025
-> Kafka broker availability at 18:32 GMT on 21st of March, 2025
-> Data recovery finished on 22nd of March, 2025 at 06:45 GMT
fields.customfield_10805:
The incident itself was caused when a second system p2prdicusfra020kafka001.fs.local in the cluster became unresponsive.
The cause for this system to become unresponsive was never identified due to the fact that it had to be forcefully power cycled. The best we know is that it froze to the point of irreconcilability by normal means.

Secondary cause was the fact that we were already trying to recover system p2prdicusfra020kafka003.fs.local in the cluster that had gone down in the morning of that day due to the raid controller failure which had to be replaced. This system being down itself did not cause an outage, but did contribute to it once another system went down.

fields.description: DUB3 SQL outage causing delay in processing for DUB3 customers, due to SOC error.
fields.customfield_10805: Earlier in the day it was determined that commands needed to be run to clean up disk space on the SQL526 node.  Due to prior experience with these routine commands in QA, we knew that they would trigger an EDR isolation.  Bart Brinkman reached out to the SOC proactively to let them know that these commands needed to be executed and that a suppression/maintenance window for this EDR trigger needed to be configured on this host.  SOC indicated that a 2-hour window had been configured.  Bart made the required change to the system, noted no abnormalities, and considered the issue handled.  At the end of the 2-hour maintenance window the EDR event was triggered due to the trigger having a 6 hour lookback window, resulting in the host being isolated.  The maintenance window that the SOC had configured did not take into account this lookback window.

fields.description: On March 21st (EDT), a Synthetics alert from Instana indicated a spike in erroneous calls in FRA. Upon investigation, we found that the services were unable to connect to Kafka because of the Kafka Outage, causing failures in sending events to Inflight . Since the issue was only in FRA, we scaled down the services in that region and redirected all traffic to AMS, where everything was functioning normally. However, events for transactions already processed in FRA couldn't be sent to Inflight, leading to a loss of visibility.
fields.customfield_10805:
On March 21st (EDT), a Synthetics alert from Instana indicated a spike in erroneous calls in FRA. Upon investigation, we found that the services were unable to connect to Kafka because of the Kafka Outage, causing failures in sending events to Inflight . Since the issue was only in FRA, we scaled down the services in that region and redirected all traffic to AMS, where everything was functioning normally. However, events for transactions already processed in FRA couldn't be sent to Inflight, leading to a loss of visibility.


Technical Details:

On March 21st (EDT), a Kafka outage occurred, preventing the API Gateway from publishing events to Kafka. In API Gateway, once transactions are successfully processed, inflight events are sent to Kafka, where they are picked up and processed to send inflight event for those transactions. However, due to the Kafka outage, transactions that had already been successfully processed could not be recorded in Inflight, leading to a loss of visibility for these transactions.

fields.description:
After a java cleanup we lost all access to the databases servers for Carters and ADV. 
This due to the /boot folder being delete incorrectly. 
This did not stop production activites for DB2, just the ability to log into the box.

A reboot was needed to restore the folder and to be extra safe we requested an outage to do that work.
fields.customfield_10805:
the 2 Clients that this happened on did not have the java folders (jd64) in the sqllib directory as per default.
All other boxes had the last java patch directory setup  in /home/db2inst1/sqllib/java/jdk64.
On the last run Carter and Adv pathcing, these clients were skipped and we might of updated them slightly differently later on with a newer verison of java patcher. 


This missing folder added to my poor coding / ansible default actions.
This section of my code...
    - name: Create tarball for old JDK
      shell: |
        cd /home/{{ instance }}/sqllib/java/jdk64
        tar cvf old_java_version_$(date +%Y-%m-%d).tar * --remove-files > /dev/null
...
But I put no checks around the folder selection. I should of really sourced it from a cfg setting or verified it before next step . If this folder does not exist, then the default on Ansible is to just stay at / level.

So at / it then zipped the entire root directory and started to then delete all files in order,  the first two folders are bin and boot. If you delete /boot then the kernel files are gone and you get kicked off the session.

comments.body:
Thank you Roy [~roy.mcdonnell@ie.ibm.com]  for the detailed analysis, 

Some questions
1) for the scripts, what user/identity is used to execute the script? 

2) for the automation code, for the code review process and test process we have today, how it can help to capture things like this?

3) Question to [~hhle@us.ibm.com] is there way to protect some folders from being deleted by mistake?

thank you!

To prevent this next time we have edited the cleanup task for java to only proced if the folders are there...



- name: Create tarball for old JDK
  shell: |
    if [ -d "/home/\{{ instance }}/sqllib/java/jdk64" ]; then
      cd /home/\{{ instance }}/sqllib/java/jdk64
      tar cvf old_java_version_$(date +%Y-%m-%d).tar * --remove-files > /dev/null
    fi
 
    if [ -d "/opt/IBM/DB2/jdk64" ]; then
      cd /opt/IBM/DB2/jdk64
      tar cvf old_java_version_$(date +%Y-%m-%d).tar * --remove-files > /dev/null
    fi
  tags: cleanup

# I am logging in as my own user but i have root privileges wihtin Ansible. I need root as the java files are stored in /opt/IBM which is owned by root. 

2. This script was one on the last scripts I created without using Watson WCA or other tools to help with its review. I now always have AI review my code and add in extra layers of security /  checks and testing. We are not developers so we have no other formal code review process. I will bring this point up with management. 


 #

For point 3 to Hoang. It should  be possible to move the java install to be owned by db2inst1 and be kept in a db2inst1 folder. This would mean we could drop the root access on Ansbile java cleanup scripts. 

Obviously we should never run "rm /" but the fact that it ran alphabetically saved us. Taking out /boot before most other folders meant we did not lose the /db2int1 or the /opt folders.

Mitigation/Prevention steps:
New process + Additional valiation with code changes deployed. 
Future: Moving java off from root and make it instant owner. Could be end of the year. Roy to share a jira to track this and close this out.
DBA is tracking the gap through a jira ticket. Roy shared the ticket for reference - https://jsw.ibm.com/browse/SREDBA-824

fields.customfield_12107:
Why did the transactions fail during the timeframe of March 8th 21:00-22:00?
Last two years transformation team used to set the  'compliance check suspension' variables to bypass the compliance checking. This time, the team didn't set this during the above time frame which caused transactions to fail during the specified time frame. 

Why did the Inflight UI unable to load the events?
The file(visibility payload) that gets saved to 21st hour directories in the file system. However InFlight UI  is trying to retrieve for files in 22 hour directory. Hence the files were unable to load in Inflight UI


Why did Inflight UI try to read file with 22nd hr?

Analysis In Progress:
Findings so far:
DB does not allow adding any time between 2:00 -2:59  hrs to a timestamp column in a EST server on the Day Light saving date. 

Column (EVENTDATETIME_UTC) of Events table in Inflight DB is indented to store the UTC timings, which of a data type "TIMESTAMP".  When there is a event with event time from 21st hr to 22 hr on the previous day of DST, it translates to 2-3 hrs UTC time on a DST date.

Ex, 8th March, 21:55 EST  -> 9th March 02:55 UTC . But server(EST) cannot have a time from 2:00-2:59 hrs on the Day Light Saving day. Hence it advance by 1 hr automatically.
fields.customfield_12106:
Two symptoms could be seen by clients:
a) data stuck: messages with non-existent timestamp of Sun Mar 9, 2025 02:00-02:59 EST failed in transformation with a red light and were reported.
b) visibility unavailable: messages with timestamp of Sat Mar 8, 2025 21:00-21:59 EST were wrongly archived so payload could not be displayed in InFlight UI.

fields.description:
Daylight Savings Time change caused issues for customers who are unable to retrieve files from 03/08 21:00 - 22:00. Due to which Customer support was unable to to resend/ restarting the failed transactions. 

As per analysis, Core Team notice that the file(visibility payload) that gets saved to 21st hour directories. However InFlight UI is trying to retrieve for files in 22 hour directory. 

As a immediate step/action, Core Team is moving the messages from 21st hour to 22nd hours so that data is available in inflight for the given Companies/ BAs shared by support. We are still processing them for the latest cases shared by the Customer Support Team.

Customer Support is reviewing the files available and resending/restarting the failed case <<Details to be added by Customer Support Team>>

The root cause for Transformation failures during the timeframe :
During Daylight Savings, when everyone switches forward one hour, the issue is that the time from 02:00 AM ET to 02:59 AM ET does not exist. Translation fails due to compliance errors in HiSpeed (TX) and the data never reaching the map. In recent years, the engineering team has put in a 'compliance check suspension' during this time window to bypass compliance checking and process the data. This year TX team  didn't set  'compliance check suspension', which caused  transactions to fail during the specified time frame with the below logs
======================================
<InfoEntry code="526" description="Compliance Check Map Name">BPN_CONTRL_TO_ACKXML</InfoEntry>
<InfoEntry code="533" description="Transaction Compliance Status">REJECT</InfoEntry>
<InfoEntry code="525" description="Transaction Accept Non-Compliant">NO</InfoEntry>
======================================


The root cause for Inflight unable to load data

Analysis in Progress:
Findings so far:
DB does not allow adding any time between 2:00 - 2:59 hrs to a timestamp column in a EST server on the Day Light saving date.

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why were messages stuck in engine queue on DUB3?
Ans: Because one of the services not properly shutdown/stopped in protocol server while executing first step of change plan. (https://jsd.wce.ibm.com/projects/WSC/queues/issue/WSC-78113)

Why 2: Why was the engine queue not processing the message.?
Ans: Engine was looking transaction details in new database servers, but all the inbound transaction details are stored in old database server, so engine components failed to process messages which is in engine queue.

Why 3: Why did the transaction not process after migrating into new SQL 2022 server?
Ans: All the messages' transactions status details were stored in old database server so broken transactions status found in new database while processing message.

Why 4: Why was it transactions stored into old SQL server?
Ans: One service was up and running and causing data to be inserted into the old database server. As a result, all the transactions are stored in old database server. 

Why 5: What could be done to fix this issue.?
Ans: We could have verified all services are shutdown/stopped in all the Protocol servers and also checked in old database that there is no new transactions are inserted in Inbound tables.

Why 6: How do we ensure this doesn't happen again?
Ans : Change to existing process : Instead of stopping and changing service to Manual Mode, we will change them to "Disable" state so that it doesn't get started automatically via other dependent services.  We will also check all the MQ queues to ensure no pending traffic before an SQL upgrade occurs.

fields.customfield_10711:
- DB team had executed a change plan to migrate SQL Server from 2019 to SQL Server 2022 and as a part of this change plan, our App Team had to stop the services, change database instances to point to the new database server and then restart the services after the migration- https://jsd.wce.ibm.com/projects/WSC/queues/issue/WSC-78113

When we restarted the services, as part of application verification Step, we found that some messages were stuck in MSMQ Engine queue. 

6:48 EST -We opened up a PTB and L3 support team was called in along with other support members. (slack channel:  #ptb-sql-upgrade-van-stuck-transactions)

- While troubleshooting, we found that one of the services was not properly stopped in one of the old protocols servers (which wasn't even used) and due to that all transactions were  getting stored in old database.
- We have inserted missing data in the new database server and successfully transferred the missing records from the old database to the new one, resolving the issue.
8:30 EST all the stuck transactions got process.

Why 2:
Documents are stuck in yellow because the connections to TP from POD44 were failing and retrying after POD44 is migrated to new RHEL8 box.

Why 3:
6 outbound connections were failing because some of the network rules are missing for the new IP

Why 4:
Firewall rules were missing because they had been removed via a decomm request for servers that had previously been using those IPs.

Why 5:
IP addresses were recycled before firewall rule cleanup was complete.

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why were some Customers not able to connect to FTP service on Dub3 ?
Ans : Because FTP server on old Win 2012 Dub3 server PRO504 was brought down.

Why 2: Why was the FTP Service on PRO 504 brought down.?
Ans : So that we could route the traffic completely to the newer Win2019 servers which had been functioning for a week now. 

Why 3: Why did the new server PRO506 not handle these FTP customers.?
Ans: The Load balancer configuration by mistake was setup such that it would only allow max limit of 5 sessions at a time on new server PRO506.

Why 4: Why was it configured to handle only 5 max connections?
Ans : There were 2 groups configured within the Load balancer & this new FTP server was by mistake put in the 2nd group which only had a max of 5 connections at a time.  So any more sessions after that would time out. This was the reason why some FTP sessions were timing out and customers were not able to connect it.  But others worked just fine. 

Why 5: What could be done to fix this issue.? 
Ans : Temporarily, we enabled the older FTP server so traffic could continue there, and after that we created a jira ticket to fix the LB configuration so that it removes the max limit of 5 connections.

Jira ticket Ref : https://jsd.wce.ibm.com/browse/WSC-78081

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1:  Why messages piled up in Inflight feeder queues?

Based on the analysis, there was Blocking and waiting on connections on NA PROD Shard 1 Inflight DB during the timeframe. This was blocking Inflight feeder to get connections with DB and not able to process the visibility related events. The blocking and waiting connections had exclusive lock on DB and was preventing any other operations to be performed. Hence application had to wait for the process to complete and then execute the next one. Thus the messages in queue was piled up.

fields.customfield_10711: On Feb 6, 2025 at ~4:00am GMT, the AppDel team pushed out patches to the OMSv1 production servers in the US region (as has been standard practice for that past several years).  Unfortunately, the Q1 2025 patches included updates to the HA Proxy service which caused that service to be restarted.  The issue was quickly addressed and service was restored.
fields.customfield_10713: LAN, TBH
fields.description: There was an unexpected service disruption in the DAL10 data center on Feb 6 which affected MQ connections for some customers in the OMSv1 US region.
fields.customfield_10805:
As part of our standard patching procedure, we pushed updates to the servers prior to the scheduled reboot.  This practice was implemented to streamline the process and shorten the outage duration.  

Although this has worked without incident for the past few years... the latest patch included an update to the HA Proxy service, which caused that service to be restarted (resulting in the service interruption).

We have updated our patching process to prevent this issue from happening in the future.  Going forward, we will not push updates prior to the scheduled reboot.  This will extend the outage duration (still well within the maintenance window), but it will ensure that we don't encounter this issue again.
fields.summary: Unexpected service disruption in DAL10 on Feb 6, 2025

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why was the Event Stream flow stopped?
- An application update was performed and the new version of the application was missing logic that was required for Event Stream data to be sent correctly.

Why 2: Why was this problem not detected sooner?
- The verification steps followed during the application update did not include verification of the Event Streams flow.
- No Kafka monitoring was implemented.

Why 3: Why did identification of the root cause take so long?
- Time was spent on a configuration problem that ended up being unrelated.
- An unrelated MQ outage (see https://jsd.wce.ibm.com/browse/RC-1393) during the incident slowed down diagnosis.
- It was discovered that the previous version of the application was not under source control, so it was not possible to identify differences between the two versions.
- The previous version of the application was manually built by an SME who is no longer with IBM, so some domain knowledge was lost.

Why 4: Why did rolling back the application change take so long?
- It was discovered that the previous version of the application had been built and deployed manually, rather than using our established CI/CD pipeline. Therefore it was not possible to use our automated rollback process. 

Why 5: Why wasn't the previous version of the application managed correctly?
- In the past, proper build and deployment procedures were not followed. This includes not contributing source code to source control and conducting out-of-band deployments.
-  This left the previous version of the application in a bad state and made upgrades and rollbacks much more difficult.
- The SME for this previous version is no longer with IBM, so critical domain knowledge was lost.
fields.customfield_12106:
The Event Stream feature was broken for several days in both NA CTE and NA Prod. Currently Michelin is the only customer using this feature, so they were the only one impacted.

During the incident timeframe, no tracking metadata was being pushed to Michelin's Kafka topic, although data was still available via InFlight APIs.

As part of the incident resolution, data from the incident timeframe was resent at a later time in both NA CTE and NA Prod.
fields.customfield_12109:
- Verification steps followed during application update were incomplete
- Missing Kafka monitoring
- Missing source code
- Knowledge lost when previous SME left IBM
- Delayed responses from customer

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: DBA wanted to add backup VIP to TSA. Hence he requested system team to bring down the backup VIP on primary server. Bringing down backup VIP to have TSA take control of it is a non-disruptive activity



Why 2: System team brought down the backup VIP on the primary server. This caused reboot of the primary db server.


Why 3: (from System team) system reported error "TS_LOC_DOWN_ST Possible malfunction on local adapter", and became unresponsive


Why 4: reboot process was started


Why 5: server was rebooted and failover has been started but because of presence of manual VP files on the not promoted active node, TSA could not bring VIP and application was not able to connect to the database.

fields.description:
On the 27 th of January at 4:48 AM EST, we received alert from zabbix, that the SFTP and FTP processes are not running. We logged in to the nodes and observed DB connectivity issue. 

The DBA team was rebuilding the HADR and the VIP through which the app connects to the DB was not reachable and the app is not able to process data. 

The DBA team resolved the issue and the app was up and running at 5:27 AM IST and all backlogs on the inbound and outbound was cleared by 5:30 AM EST

comments.body: [~trungng@us.ibm.com] to work with [~hhle@us.ibm.com] to get more information on this ticket and update here.

Why 1:
Why MQ failover happened

There was issue in IBMCloud backend infrastructure which caused network outage to access NFS shared storage.

Why 2:
Why MQ was not able to connect NFS

Root Cause provided by IBMCloud "Full root cause remains under investigation, but preliminary investigation has identified that a BGP routing update sourced from a single MZR was interpreted as malformed by a subset of our network switches globally, which resulted in a BGP reset being invoked by the affected devices. "

Why 3:
Why OMS jvms and external apps were not connecting to MQ and

When the MQ servers were not able to connect to the shared storage, both instances were down and the listener were shutdown .

Thank you [~hhle@us.ibm.com] for the updates and initial investigation information from IBM cloud.
We will wait to hear for final RCA and why it happened, why was it not proactively monitored/identified by IBM cloud.

Uploaded Final CIR from ibmcloud for the RCA
[^PRB0094081 - ID_0004335_FINAL.pdf]

RCA based on FINAL CIR from ibmcloud.

 

"Root cause investigation identified that a service provisioning update in one region, combined with a latent configuration issue in that same region, resulted in a BGP routing update with a large number of ASNs being propagated out to other regions / network devices. This large BGP routing update was interpreted by a subset of our network switch devices as malformed, which in turn triggered a BGP routing reset.
The configuration which caused the issue did not exist in any other region and has been removed from the network as part of the corrective actions. We have also implemented a protection mechanism to filter route updates carrying an unusually large number of ASNs at this layer of the network. These actions will prevent a recurrence. 
Additionally, we completed an assessment to determine if any additional safeguards are required to prevent a recurrence and we have determined that no further actions are required."

resolution.description: Work has been completed on this issue.
resolution.name: Complete

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1:  MQ QMs were offline due to GPFS servers being down.


Why 2:  GPFS servers were offline due to underlying storage being unavailable.


Why 3:  Underlying storage was unavailable because it was unintentionally unmapped from hosts during change plan.


Why 4:  Human error during execution of a change plan resulted in impacted storage being removed from more hosts than intended.


Why 5: The QM was not getting started since one of the queue had old messages and a size more than 100 GB which was not cleared by the respective team. 

Why 6: Why the queue, BPN.TO.INFLIGHT.APIS.DATA has old files with huge file size which was not cleared ? 
The payload sync process for InFlight APIs accumulates orphan data messages over time. We need to investigate the cause for this and implement a fix to stop it from happening in the future. Issue https://github.ibm.com/WCE-SCBN/inflight-web-features/issues/2129 has been created to track this work.
fields.customfield_12106: After storage outage was resolved in NA Prod, visibility (Inflight and ERN) were offline until 3:20pm, and visibilty data was not current for all queues until 6:47pm ET.
fields.customfield_10711:
1:06pm - ERN system have connected to MQ and cleared queues, but are not receiving new traffic from Dispatcher
1:12pm - NA Prod CDT appears to have recycled (likely MQ services being restarted)
1:15pm - VAN reports that they can connect to QM.FFIEC and receiver had to be restarted to process 12.4k messages in SFTP5 queue
1:35pm - All QMs are available and processing except for QM that services visibility (Inflight and ERN).  Impacted QM tries to start but terminates abnormally after loading approx 57k messages
1:35-1:45pm - SEV1 opened with IBM MQ Support team (need clarification on time)
2:04pm - MQ Support engineer joins incident huddle to troubleshoot, requests logs and traces which are being collected
3:04pm - MQ Support engineer notifies that there is a flaw that matches the description of our issue, suggests that we can install a fixpack that will resolve it.  Discussion ensues over options to install fixpack without thoroughly testing it in QA, rollback procedures, and alternatives.
3:12pm - Decision is made to try to restart QM in stand-alone config rather than HA before attempting fixpack.
3:20pm - QM successfully started in stand-alone mode, MQ team begins restarting queues/channels to restore message flow.  It is noted that this will likely take several hours due to the backlog of messages and additional incoming messages.
4:07pm - Number of threads allocated to QM is increased to allow faster processing (Kamlesh Silag)
4:29pm - ERN queues are all current
5:40pm - All queues are current except queues to archive and BTI
6:25pm - Archive queues are current
6:47pm - All queues are current

comments.body: [~trungng@us.ibm.com] to check with [~vereyes@ibm.com] on updating the rca and assigning a team member to owrk on it

Why 1:
Why pods were stuck in Init state

The pods could not mount the nfs share

Why 2:
Why pods were not able to mount to the shared volume disks

the ibmcloud backend dns service was having issue, causing the system and pods failed to resolve the dns servers

Why 3:
Why the connection was timing out from k8s node to nfs mount connection

the ibmcloud backend dns service was having issue, causing the system and pods failed to resolve the dns servers

Why 4:
Why DNS was not getting resolved from k8s nodes to nfs devices

the ibmcloud backend dns service was having issue

 

 

RCA provided by ibmcloud team.

"Root cause investigation with the storage vendor suggests the issue was likely triggered by a firmware defect in the storage vendors software. When the defect is triggered, the DNS service listener will go into a closed vs. listening state when a service policy change is applied, and the DNS listener service configuration is present in the policy. The logical interfaces are then unable to process new mounts until the issue is resolved through a DNS listener restart.   "

Thank you [~hhle@us.ibm.com] for the update on root cause. While we have the RCA from IBM cloud, we may also need to understand how this is mitigated. Could you pls followup with IBM cloud to get these additional informaiton?

*The issue was likely triggered by a firmware defect in the storage vendors software *- Is this fix received from the storage vendor? If not, how this was mitigated and any fix/workaround applied is a permanent one?

The final Customer Incident Report from IBMCloud
[^PRB0094113 - ID_0004317_FINAL.pdf]

RCA based on the final CIR from ibmcloud

 

"Root cause investigation identified this issue is linked to an update in the storage vendors software library, which altered DNS functionality. When the defect is triggered, the DNS service listener will go into a closed vs. listening state when a service policy change is applied, and the DNS listener service configuration is present in the policy. The logical interfaces are then unable to process new mounts until the issue is resolved through a DNS listener restart. The issue was reproducible in environments with similar configurations and necessitated an infrastructure patch to restore regular DNS service operations. Overall risk level for reoccurrence is deemed to be LOW as we have temporarily halted service policy updates while we work with the vendor to deploy a fix. In addition, this issue is limited to new mounts and remounts only and workloads with existing mounts should not be affected by this defect.
To reduce the potential for reoccurrence of this issue, IBM Cloud Specialists will be upgrading storage clusters, which is planned for late June."

resolution.description: Work has been completed on this issue.
resolution.name: Complete

fields.customfield_10711:
11:34am - First issues with storage occur in IBM Cloud FRA02
12:21pm - Anish Bruce reports that GPFS folders for QM were unavilable
→ #swat_qm_sipro02_qm_is-not_accessible_eu_prod

12:24pm - Mark Desautels reports that GPFS filesystem for MQ folder has gone into a stale state
12:27pm-12:32pm - Desautels reboots GPFS server nodes
12:35pm-12:37pm - Desautels restarts MQ services on impacted QMs
12:40pm - Sathiskumar Palaniappan reports that service has been restored and there is no outbound backlog.  Inbound backlog of 1038 messages that needed to be re-sent.
1:05pm - Kevin McFerrin and Phill Hubbard join call with CEVA to explain the situation as we understand it.  CEVA requests a preliminary update including actions taken to resolve the issue.
1:17pm - Case CS4225044 opened with IBM Cloud requesting RCA for storage issues in FRA02, assuming issue has been resolved.
1:30pm-1:38pm - A second wave of storage path redundancy loss is observed in FRA02 data center, but this time we did not observe "all paths down" condition.  OCP team noted some storage containers were restarting.  Case with IBM cloud is updated to indicate that we are still experiencing issues.
1:58pm - IBM Cloud storage support confirms there was a storage issue that impacted FRA02 data center that was the cause of this incident.
2:41pm - Details provided to support for relay to CEVA regarding current status and restoration steps that were taken:

"Start of incident: 11:34AM ET
Resolved time: 12:37PM ET
Multiple systems in IBM EU data center reported lost connectivity to storage volumes, including filesystems used by MQ queue managers.  This resulted in MQ going offline.  Restarting of GPFS systems and MQ services was required once storage connectivity was restored.  Service was restored at 12:37pm ET.
Multiple IBM Cloud data centers are currently experiencing internal network issues resulting in multiple issues.  We believe that this issue is the likely cause of lost storage connectivity.  Though IBM SCBN is currently processing CEVA data, we have been informed that the overall issue has not been fully resolved.  SCBN team is presently online and monitoring the situation and is prepared in the event that there is further disruption."

2:53pm - IBM Cloud storage support notes that there was a second wave of issues at approximately 1:30pm as the previous issue was being mitigated.  They assured us that the issue was resolved and should not happen again. 
2:58pm - Jason Salyers reports there are still 20 transactions in a deferred status for CEVA/Amazon Turkey and further cleanup is required.
3:12pm - Protocol team requests a Tx expert to investigate deferred transactions
3:14pm - Additional details provided to support for relay to CEVA with status update:

"IBM Cloud has confirmed an internal incident which caused network degradation affecting multiple locations starting around 2025-01-23 16:33:00 UTC.
During this time, IBM SCBN experienced connectivity failures when connecting to IBM Cloud services, including storage services.
IBM Cloud team has identified the root cause, isolated the issue, and are working on investigation which will have an incident report available to us when complete.
The IBM Cloud team also observed that while mitigation was being completed, some services experienced a second occurrence, which IBM SCBN noted with redundancy loss to volumes again around 18:30 UTC.  According to IBM Cloud team, there should be no chance of a re-occurrence."

5:12pm - Tx team do not see any errors from Hispeed and suspect visibility issue.  Core team engaged to investigate.  Also requested SCBN Support to engage with customer to see if deferred messages had been delivered.
→ #ptb-na-prod-qgatewayngd-qm-bpn1-bpn-to-archive-data-orphan-messages

7:16pm - Tx team found that the messages are stuck in embpoller responsible for pre & post processor.  Worked with support to restart the flow from BPNST.
7:25pm - Status for deferred messages is green, all data has been processed.

fields.description:
h2. Incident Summary

*Problem Description*

While upgrading the SCN SI nodes from 6.0.3.1 to 6.1.2.1, the upgrade had passed all steps and when live traffic was opened, the pickup times were not getting updated on CNET. We had stopped the pods in 15 mins, but the traffic that has gone through in the mean time had to be reprocessed by CNET.

*Impact*

Messages that were consumed by the application after the upgrade has issues with delivery to customers (5884) and messages picked up by customers has visibility issues (3563). All of the messages were reprocessed by VAN by 10/22/2024 02:12 EST
No customer cases were created for the incident.

*Root Cause*

On the 19th of January, we were upgrading SCN SI nodes and after the upgrade we have done verification using a Test mailslot (SISXSFT) which has been processed successfully on both app and CNET side. After this we have opened the live traffic and was observing all processes on the queuewatcher, but found no PickupTimeProcessor’s, which gets triggered after customers successfully pick their messages from the respective RECEIVE maillsots. 
We didn’t want any impact on the live traffic and did a backout successfully to the older version from the upgraded version. But the messages that were in the RECEIVE folders of mailslots when we allowed live traffic had to be resent from CNET as these are not picked up by customers yet. 
On further analysis of the properties files, we observed one of the file in gis/properties called visibility.properties was updated by the upgrade in which the bp event triggers for pickuptime processor were commented. This in turn did not trigger the pickup time processor which posts the PU time to CNET

*Resolution*

We had to backout to the older version first so that the further processing was happening and only documents that were processed between 12:30 AM to 4:30 AM would be resent from CNET. We had to write queries on the database to get the files that were not picked up yet by customers and shared the batch numbers with CNET for re processing.

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why was there a delay in outbound AS2 traffic ?
Ans : Because MSMQ http queue size had gone up to 40000 messages.

Why2: Why did MQ Queue size reach 40,000 messages.
Ans: From 12:30 - 12:52, Time Factory sent Office Depot 14,000 AS2 AIN interchange messages.  And then at 14:43 they sent another boat load of thousands of AIN interchanges.

Why 3: Why did Office depot send so many AIN interchange messages ?
Ans : Waiting on Office depot for their response. But typically when observing such a high condition, we  suspend the mailslots once we detect such a high volume.

Why 4: What could we have done to detect this issue or why did we not suspend the mailslot earlier  ?
Ans : Due to technical issue in zabbix we didn't get the Alert.  We got a huge number of transactions in a very short period, hence the detection didn't work as expected. This is the first occurrence of such a case.  We will work on ensuring the alerting still occurs, even if there is a delay due to high volume.
fields.customfield_12106:
Outbound AS2 traffic was delayed for 4 hrs.
Customers impacted: 
CCI AS2
PHILLIPS 66 CO SI-Dev AS2
MEDLINE INDUSTR
fields.customfield_12109:
Zabbix alerting did not trigger.  There is an issue with the configuration which might have occurred when we moved to the new zabbix system.

Also due to high volume in a very short interval, the zabbix alerting might not have picked up the spike.
fields.customfield_10711:
- One of the support team members - Mike Flynn noticed one of his customers not getting any outbound data while he was observing some traffic.  

13:19 EST: slack  #ptb-dub3-as2-not-delivery.
- This opened up a PTB and L3 support team was called in along with other support members.

- After troubleshooting further we found the MSMQ queue size was at 42000 which was a significantly high number.  We saw saw the queue size increasing gradually.  
- As part of troubleshooting, we restarted Outbound As2 service from the DUB3 protocol server but it did not have the desired effect. 
- From the MQ viewer http queue, we observed the mailslot of Office Depot which was having 14000 messages in the queue and realised that this could be the cause of the traffic jam.  
- Next we Suspended Office Depot mailslot from the WAT and also asked the Support team to Pause the Inbound messages coming to Center.
- This caused a slow down in the queue buildup and also started recovering the queues. 
- Just before restarting, we also saw the WAT server crashing due to low memory and had to restart IIS to bring back the WAT and MQ service.
- After this, the existing traffic started flowing normally and after that MQ http queue came back to normal after 1 hr. 
- Next we unsuspended the Office Depot mailslot, and that traffic started flowing and existing queue build of 8000 messages cleared up.  
- After that Support team also resumed the Office depot incoming traffic   and that also started flowing normally. 
- After 4.5 hrs Dub3 server came back to normal.

Issue was reported from the Support team that there was a delay in delivering data from Dub3 for some customers as shown below. 
Mail slots: 

Preliminary investigation revelled that Data was still flowing and many customers were still receiving data.  Upon detailed investigation, we found that there were 42,000 messages stuck in the MS MQ queue. Due to this reason other traffic was getting affected and once we identified a specific customer Office Depot which was sending thousands of messages, (14000) we suspended the maillot and after that traffic started flowing normally.  The queues recovered and the issue got resolved.

fields.customfield_12107:
Why 1: Why there are oldest messages > 10 minutes present in IBMB2B.TO.EUPRDSCBN.XMITQ queue?
 - The in flow was more than the out flow.
 - More number of uncommitted messages than the usual.

Why2: Why the QM is not bounced?
- Bouncing of QM takes more time when there is a significant depth in the queue. Which might result to have more queue pileup.

Why3: Why the MQ traces are not collected?
- Based on past experience, IBM MQ team prefers to have traces from both IBM and CEVA for a better evaluation. 
- As we engaged MQ team from IBM and CEVA, the issue got resolved by its own.
fields.customfield_12106:
The issue started around 6:42AM EST (5:12PM IST) and IBM has got an alert when the oldest message time reached above 10 minutes and the queue depth was around 1.2K. Though there was depth in the queue, the messages were getting processed.

The peak depth observed for the queue was around 24K.

Around 9:22AM EST(7:52PM IST), the queue depth started reducing faster and it became 0 by 9:29AM EST(7:59PM IST).
The transactions are not impacted though there was a delay during the time.
fields.customfield_10711:
01/09/2025 6:42 AM EST: The issue started where the depth in the queue IBMB2B.TO.EUPRDSCBN.XMITQ getting increased

01/09/2025 6:52 AM EST: Protocol team got an alert for oldest message for the queue IBMB2B.TO.EUPRDSCBN.XMITQ. The queue depth at that time was around 800

01/09/2025 07:00 AM EST : SCBN MQ team analyzed the MQ logs and no errors or exception found.

01/09/2025 07:09 AM EST: Protocol team has started the PTB and the queue depth was 1.2K and oldest message was 10 minutes.

01/09/2025 07:14 AM EST: Support Manager engaged and monitored channel.

01/09/2025 07:20 AM EST: The depth of the queue reduced to 513 and the oldest message time reduced below 5 minutes.

01/09/2025 07:25 AM EST: The depth again increased to 1750 and the oldest message time was 10 minutes. 

01/09/2025 07:30 AM EST : Engaged Network team to analyze the traffic between the source and destination.

01/09/2025 07:48 AM EST : Though the Sender channel was up and running, SCBN MQ team restarted the channel to eliminate any connectivity issue.

01/09/2025 07:55 AM EST : Network team confirmed that there is no error at network side and the traffic was through between the source and destination.

01/09/2025 07:56 AM EST : Queue depth reached 8.1K and oldest message time was 33 minutes. SCBN team started engaging customer support to notify CEVA.

01/09/2025 08:20 AM EST : We observed increase of uncommitted messages in the queue. Which is generally caused due to large files. Checked the files sizes and didn't find any exceptional case.

01/09/2025 08:33 AM EST : Jason is asked to create the support ticket to CEVA.

01/09/2025 08:41 AM EST : Jason created SEV1 ticket to CEVA TS018218205 

01/09/2025 09:05 AM EST : CEVA opened a bridge. 

01/09/2025 09:12 AM EST : IBM explained the issue and CEVA has checked network and MQ logs at CEVA side and confirmed nothing unusual.

01/09/2025 09:20 AM EST :  Decided to take MQ trace at both IBM and CEVA Side to analyze further.

01/09/2025 09:22 AM EST :  Observed that the queue depth started reducing.

01/09/2025 09:29 AM EST :  The queue became current and oldest message time was zero.

01/09/2025 09:35 AM EST : Since the queue was cleared, it was decided to take further follow up if the issue occurs again

fields.customfield_10709:
# DEV
- Continue to monitor the queue depth and see any issues and coordinate with CEVA 
    Alerts Already in place at IBM side 

- CEVA and IBM to analyze the logs further to see if any issues noticed.
   IBM and CEVA analyzed the MQ error logs and found nothing unusual.

- MQ and Network Traces to be captured at both CEVA and IBM side at the same time if the issue reoccurs

- SCBN MQ team to capture the traces independent of combined traces for any such incidents. 
  A SOP for CEVA and SCBN MQ Team has been defined to follow during the incident to capture the trace, get the Queue manager kernel, logger and queue dumps. 

- A ticket has been raised to IBM MQ team to analyze the scenario in case of unusual number of uncommitted messages - TS018306465.

Based on the suggestions we have reviewed the following
 * batch size
 * batch interval
 * number of remote queues
 * number of producers vs consumers (remote queue vs XMITQ)

- Check with systems team on CPU Utilization / Memory
 Systems team didn't find any resource or load issues on those MQ nodes during that time. Any change in the performance numbers throughout that period was also NOT observed

# NETWORK
We are investigating (with IBM Cloud and Fortinet) any potential bottleneck on the FRA02 firewall.
During the MQ outage we could experience several TCP retransmission messages in the saved packet capture files.
IBM Cloud ticket: CS4216144
(Need to wait for the end of the examination of the firewall to be able to make clear statement regarding the bottleneck.)

fields.customfield_10805: java using incorrect certificate
fields.summary: SST - 400 errors due to SST using wrong client certificate

comments.body:
Questions for the RCA discussion:
 * Why was the expired certificate being picked up? If this hasn't happened earlier, what caused it this time?
 * Do we need to update our cert renewal processes to add this step of deleting the older cert and/or restarting selfserve whenever there is such a cert update being done?
 * We didn't realize the older cert was being used until customers noticed failures and reported the cases with us. Was/can there be additional monitoring in place to identify such errors proactively so we can minimize customer impact?

*Root Cause:*
The primary cause of the outage was the presence of an expired certificate in the system. Although we had monitoring systems in place to identify expired certificates, the expired certificate was not removed as per our established runbook procedures, which had been used for several years. Upon investigation, it was determined that the Java application inadvertently picked the expired certificate, leading to the outage. 

*Resolution:*
To resolve the issue, the expired certificate was removed from the system, and SelfServe was restarted. This action allowed the application to recognize and utilize the active certificate (selfserve25), restoring normal operations. 

*Preventive Measures:*
In light of this incident, we have updated our runbook to include a critical step: the removal of any expired certificates immediately after a new certificate is added to the system. This adjustment will help prevent similar occurrences in the future and ensure that our systems consistently operate with valid certificates.
This ticket can been closed as resolution, action items is done.
Resolution completed.
